abstract: German task force created to determine provenance of art found in apartment of Cornelius Gurlitt, which is suspected of being looted by Nazis, identifies ownership of only five of over 1,200 pieces; officials defend project, which cost almost $2 million, against critics frustrated by perceived slowness and lack of transparency.
lead_paragraph: A German task force set up to determine ownership of more than 1,200 pieces of art was able to identify only five, prompting criticism from Jewish groups about the pace and intensity of the effort.

headline.main: Few Answers on True Owners of Art Found in Gurlitt Trove
headline.print_headline: Few Answers on True Owners of Art Found in Trove

snippet: A German task force set up to determine ownership of more than 1,200 pieces of art was able to identify only five, prompting criticism from Jewish groups about the pace and intensity of the effort.
